Prop: 4 The parts of bodies & their Interstices 
must not be lesse then of Some definite bignesse to render 
them opake & coloured. For the opakest bodyes, if their parts 
be Subtily divided (as Mettalls by being dissolued in acid 
Menstruums, &c) become p[er]fectly transparent And you 
may also remember, that in the 8th Observac[i]on there was 
no reflexion at the Superficies of the Object-Glasses 
where they were very near one another though they did 
not absolutely touch. <s>And in the 17th Observac[i]on the 
reflexion of the water-bubble, where they were very near 
one another though they did not absolutely touch <\s> And 
in the 17th Observac[i]on the reflexion of the water-bubble 
where it became thinnest, was almost insensible So as to 
cause the Apparac[i]ons of very black Spots.
On these grounds I conceive it is, that water, Salt,
Glasse, Stones, & Such like Substances, are transparent. For,
upon divers Considerac[i]ons they Seeme to be as porous as other 
bodyes, but yet their pores & parts too small to cause any 
Opacity.
Prop: 5 The Transparent parts of bodyes according 
to their Seu[er]all Sizes must <u>reflect <\u> rayes of one colour, and 
<u>transmitt <\u> those of another, on the Same Grounds, that thinn 
plates or Bubbles doe reflect or transmitt those rayes.
And this I take to be the ground of all their Colours.
For if a thinn’d or plated body, wch being of an even 
thicknesse appears all ouer of one uniforme colour, Should 
be broken into Fragments of the same thickness with the 
plate, I See no reason why a heap of those fragments should 
not constitute a powder of the same colour which the Plate 
exhibited before it was broken. And the parts of all naturall 
bodies, being like So many fragments of a Plate must on the 
Same grounds exhibit the Same colours.
